title: Mid-1800's Book Cover
content:
Greetings,  
I’m trying to recreate the flavor of this delightful book cover, and I thought you fellow typophiles might have some suggestions for similars to the three typefaces—which are obviously hand drawn—that I could use as starting ponts.

Your help and expertise is greatly appreciated, as always!

PS: For our American friends—hope you’re having a great holiday weekend.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20081026074328im_/http:/www.typophile.com/files/HGW_sample_6117.jpg)

author: malbright

comments.content:
Hi Mike,

This is a very subjective question, since it’s hard to guess how much ’tweaking’ you want to do. I looked through hand-drawn lettering fonts for each of the three styles on the cover. (1) = HOW GAMBLERS WIN; (2) = OR THE SECRETS OF; and (3) = ADVANTAGE PLAYING. I looked for fonts without layering that you would use for (1) and (3).

These would be fonts I might try for these (just ideas based on a quick look):

(1): [Ad Hoc](http://web.archive.org/web/20081026074328/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/ad-hoc/), [Rekord](http://web.archive.org/web/20081026074328/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontfont/ff-rekord/), [Repent](http://web.archive.org/web/20081026074328/http:/www.dafont.com/repent.font), [Sinclair](http://web.archive.org/web/20081026074328/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/redrooster/sinclair-script-rr/)

(2): [Escher Hand](http://web.archive.org/web/20081026074328/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/p22/escher-hand/), [Kooky](http://web.archive.org/web/20081026074328/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/kooky-bt/)

(3): [Moulin Rouge Solide](http://web.archive.org/web/20081026074328/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/t26/toulouse-lautrec-moulin-rouge/)

- Mike Yanega

Hi MIke,  
Thanks so much for the suggestions.

Moulin Rouge could work quite well. Would love to find fonts for the others that are a bit closer ... but these are excellent ideas and much appreciated.

Cheers.

Another suggestion for 2): [Aeolian Demi](http://web.archive.org/web/20081026074328/http:/www.fontbros.com/cgi-bin/commerce.cgi?preadd=action&key=HAFO-AEDB#) by Harold Lohner.

I have also been trying to avoid popular fonts, because I think the ’antiqueness’ would be offset by something that looked too familiar.

- Mike Yanega

A possibility for 1): [Road Jester](http://web.archive.org/web/20081026074328/http:/www.fontbros.com/cgi-bin/commerce.cgi?preadd=action&key=HAFO-ROJE#), also by Harold Lohner. You’d need to pull in the points of the serifs, but the flaring might match the cover lettering fairly well.

- Mike Yanega
